author: darren gladstone
text: i hate using the mouse. between trackballs, points, and pads, it's no wonder i threw my old notebook in the corner after i got my hands on fujitsu's lifebook b112 mini-notebook. with the b112, i just tap the screen and i'm on my way. and this isn't some wince handheld: we're talking a fully operational windows 98 machine with an 8.4-inch touchscreen display. no longer can my pda-slinging buddies one-up me with the ability to use a stylus or pinky to point right on the screen. whether you want to quickly highlight and delete a paragraph in word, run a powerpoint presentation, or dabble with an art or photo-editing program, it seems more natural pointing at the screen than using a mouse. better yet, with yahoo! maps or expedia maps, a touch can zero you in on your location. the touchscreen drivers that came with my beta unit work like a charm. of course, if you've been bred to live and die by the mouse, this is still a fast and sleek machine with a comfortable - and forgiving - trackpoint.the lifebook is no larger than a hardcover and weighs less than 3 pounds, but beneath its magnesium-alloy casing there lurks a 233mmx processor, 32 megs of ram (expandable to 96 mbytes), and a 3.2-gbyte hard drive. i was equally impressed to eke out about three hours of moderate use from the unit before it quit. the heat-damping cushion on the bottom, however, can still use some work (though it does make a soothing heat pad for my lap). the keyboard is also comfortable: i easily cranked out this review with my stumpy fingers.as a final test, i played some games. imagine - bad guys exploding as you point a finger in their direction! i tried x-wing vs. tie fighter, quake ii, and interstate '76. in each case i found that a touchscreen sounds good on paper, but as soon as i tapped the screen, the view shifted and i'd empty all my ammo into the first target i saw. in short, tapping your way to victory isn't as easy as it sounds.overall, i'll regret having to part with my review copy of the b112. giving my old notebook the finger won't provide the same sense of satisfaction.lifebook b112: $1,599. fujitsu pc corp.: +1 (408) 935 8800, (888) 466 8434, street credroom serviceorganize in stereoa time to gromany unhappy returnsthe wrath of youking of lost vegastouchscreens are betterurban legendmusicjust outta betareadmehere to reternitynatural selectionexquisite computingno village idiothigh dramacontributors
